dialogues.text: On the sound track: VOICES, distorted, animalistic. The TITLE comes up over the abstract images. Some of the are runic, mystical. The title fades out. The VOICES distill to one familiar VOICE. The swirling shapes begin to focus as we MOVE back. We're watching a "screen" suspended in space. ON THE SCREEN: An impassioned man speaks to a rapt crowd Hitler Youth. ADOLF HITLER, at the peak of his power. HITLER (German, no subtitles) We will pass from the scene, but for you, Germany will live on. And when we are gone, it will be your duty to hold high in your clenched fist the banner which we raised out of nothingness. And I know it cannot be otherwise, for you are flesh of our flesh and blood of our blood, and the same spirit that rules us burns in your young brains. Today, standing on this stage, I am but a tiny part of that which extends beyond, over the whole of Germany, and we want you, German boys and German girls, to absorb all our hopes for the future of that Germany. We want to be one nation, and you, my youth, shall become that nation. We want an end to classes and class divisions, and you must keep such ideas from looming within yourselves. THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 As he forcefully gesticulates, we MOVE further back from screen and PAN across a dark, DANK, DUNGEON-LIKE CELL. HITLER (0.S. in German) We want to see one Reich in the future, and you must prepare yourselves for it. We want this nation to be obedient, and you must practice obedience. We want this nation to be peace-loving but brave as well, and you must be peace-loving. You must be peace-loving and brave at the same time.

THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 The morning of May 2, 1924 in Landsberg Prison. He walks over, drops the folder on the Typist's desk. To the sounds of MARCHING from the screen, Adolf turns to mirror, pushes his hair back and adjusts his uniform. ADOLF (to the Typist) In other countries, why do they keep the German title, "Mein Kampf", instead of translating it to "My Struggle?" ON THE CELL SCREEN: Hitler reviewing the troops at a para more of the soldiers goose-stepping (abstracted).

dialogues.speaker: THE MIRROR
dialogues.text: The image focuses: Adolf lit by one source, off screen, h rimmed in light, still "frozen". He moves. He seems to have a lamp in his hand, just off f He moves his arm slowly in an arc, studying the way the l affects the moving light and shadows on his face. He moves the lamp behind his head, "back-lighting" himsel throwing his face into darkness. ADOLF (to the Typist, 0.S.) The sun is uncontrollable, unforgiving. With the sun you can't shape or sculpt reality. When in front of him, the lamp has a flattering effect on wrinkles. He lets it linger here.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: I hate the sun. He "places" the light, and takes a dramatic-speech pose. ADOLF'S POV: A vague outline of a camera stands behind an side of the mirror. ON ADOLF: He checks his pose in the mirror again. CLICK: The image freezes into a still photograph.1 CUT AHEAD TO: Adolf, unsatisfied, places the still photo easel, studies the pose captured there, and then the mirr then repeats the pose, to perfect it. THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 CLICK: Another portrait is taken. The image freezes to a CUT AHEAD TO: Adolf, still unsatisfied, again places the photo on an easel, nervously pushes his hair back from hi and then obsessively uses the mirror to improve. CLICK. CLICK. CLICK. Photo after pose after photo after pose. He never quite g right. But it gets better. By the last pose, it's a strik freeze-frame of passion and righteous rage.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Hot coals turn from red to black as they cool. Details of horrific "degenerate" art (by Otto Dix). Chunks of mortar stones in a Speerian cell wall crack and crumble away -- from beyond the wall, barely revealing human bones undern The image shakes subtly, a deep vibration, as if in an earthquake.

dialogues.speaker: A HAND-WRITTEN ENVELOPE ADDRESSED TO THE FUHRER
dialogues.text: A hand pulls a letter from the envelope. It's worn and ta obviously read and re-read many times.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Let's enter one more into the record. (pulls it from envelope, reads as the Typist types, 0.S.) This is from April, 1935. A woman from Berlin. "My fervently adored Fuhrer. You have a birthday, and we know only two ardent wishes: May everything in our fatherland be now and in the future just as you want it to be and may God provide that you be preserved for us forever. Your loyal, E.E." ON THE CELL SCREEN behind him: boy and girl members of th Youth exercise in strict, attractive formation. Adolf smiles pridefully, puts the letter into a basket fu hundreds more letters like it. Affixed to each is a posta of a Hitler portrait. Adolf sorts through them, selects a one he likes.

dialogues.speaker: MOVE THROUGH MODEL CITY TOWARDS GIANT DOME
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 It's a fantasy land, a future Nazi utopia. The architecture is huge stone slabs, thick columns. Towe over all is the "main building," a gargantuan exaggeratio scale with a huge dome. Looking up from inside this misproportioned city, we see lean over the buildings. His hair fallen down over his fo Goebbels appears behind him.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: There is magic in enormity, my Little Doctor. He lifts a scaled model of the Eiffel tower into view, se down next to his own eagle-topped tower. He seems disappo discover that the French tower is taller.

dialogues.speaker: THE BASE OF THE NAZI TOWER
dialogues.text: Adolf lifts it, slips a block under it. We TILT UP to see it is now just taller than the Eiffel Tower. Adolf underp pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Overwhelming, like a dominant father.

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS
dialogues.text: Yes, but the art is in disguising the technique. Brutality must be wrapped in velvet. That's what distinguishes us from, say... a thug like Stalin. Goebbels pulls a three-inch roll of red cloth from his po It's tied up with gold string. Goebbels reaches to attach a building... Adolf walks toward the Typist, begins dictating quietly.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Wagner made the exorbitant demand that the stage become an hypnotic instrument under the power of the artist. I imposed the same demand on Germany. He walks back to Goebbels, who has decorated Germania for parade, turning the main mall into something almost festi

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 History is an error to be rewritten by the visionary playwright.

dialogues.speaker: FROM GERMANIA STREET LEVEL
dialogues.text: Looking up at the front of the massive main building. The entire "mall" is now decorated with Nazi flags on bui flags suspended from light poles, etc. Dr. Goebbels, just above the skyline, unfurls a long roll cloth -- the largest red Nazi flag. It drops down the len the tall tower. Adolf inspects it, nods.

dialogues.speaker: A TOY SOLDIER STANDS ON A STREET OF THE MODEL CITY
dialogues.text: Adolf's hand picks it up. We follow it along the street towards the huge dome. The dome's top is lifted off. We rise up over the lip, hearing CROWDS!

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE DOME
dialogues.text: Adolf's hand places the toy soldier on a giant podium. We discover ADOLF'S FACE, peering in over the top. ANGLE UP at the tiny man on the huge podium, Adolf's proportionately enormous head looking down on us.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: While Wagner brought the German myths to the operatic stage, I brought them to the world. I am the superman, a Teutonic knight on the quest for the Holy Grail. Compared to me, Wagner was a minimalist. He says it with no self-irony. Goebbels watches him with chameleon face that serves whatever Adolf projects onto h WAGNERIAN MUSIC builds aggressively, as if to dominate Ad put him in his place. Adolf's mood changes. The hollow br wanes. Humility overtakes him. The music crescendos. Followed by the roar of applause. BEAMS OF LIGHT form a mini "cathedral of lights" behind t THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 TINY SWASTIKAS flutter down onto Germania. Adolf hears th applause, re-inflates himself. He gently sprinkles swasti from his hand, like a gardener, from above the city.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Wait... I thought you said our count was five million seven hundred thousand. Hands roll a map of 1930's Europe onto a war table.

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: They're using the six million figure. GENERAL GOERING is dressed in one of his elaborate unifor numerous medals. Dangling from his belt is a large ceremo battle sword in its ornate scabbard. He stands back, with fist on its handle.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Typical. A clever exaggeration. (thinks) Let's use that figure, Goering. All the better for us. History likes round numbers. Adolf jots figures on a piece of paper near the map. He looks out over Europe.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: The war total was 55 million.... ADOLF (cont'd) Out of that the camps and the death squads were responsible for only eleven or twelve million.

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: Twelve.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Could we say that over half of those were non-Jews?

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: We could say that over fifty percent were Christians, atheists and Pagans.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 Awkward language.

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: What term covers Gypsies, Polish intelligentsia, Russian upper strata, prisoners of war, French and Yugoslavian partisans, political opponents...

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Should we use "gentiles?" (calculates in his mind) But... if twelve million were liquidated and six million were Jews... Or is five point seven...? Scheissa! Why can't I get accurate numbers?! Where's Himmler?!

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: I would stand behind this wording: "Almost half the dead were from the Christian world." Adolf considers, then nods, resigning himself to this.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Yes... And yet the Jews take they're removal so personally.

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: What strikes me is that little notice is taken of the fact that the first biological cleansing eliminated German nationals: The disabled, the retarded, the mentally ill...

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: And the bed wetters.... ADOLF (cont'd) (shakes his head) The useless eaters. Commenced, September one, nineteen-thirty nine.

dialogues.speaker: GOERING
dialogues.text: Actually it was October first. You back-dated the decree one month to correspond with the first day of the war.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Tidier... War for living space. War for race purification. All begun on the same day. He says this without emotion. All business. Cold.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Move up along the side of the uniform, to discover a long in its sheath, hanging from the belt. We travel further u the side, around to the front, to above the collar where sticks out to hold up the hat.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CELL SCREEN
dialogues.text: Followed by other peaceful images of life at the Berghof. IN THE CELL: Eva watches these images while Adolf flips t loose photos lying on open pages of a photo album.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Look at you posing for my camera, as if you didn't know I was there. Adolf ignores her, stays focused on the images. They're " photos," of Hitler with Eva, with his dog, in various hom settings. Adolf wears a hat in a few of them.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do I look more mysterious in a hat? Eva turns from the home movies, shakes her head. He then hatless picture on top of the hat picture, and moves on. She notices a photo of Hitler with Himmler and Goering. C to their costumes, Hitler's is noticeably plain.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Why did you never wear an official army, SA or SS uniform?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Better to remain undefined. (stops, reflects on this) Suggestive indefiniteness. She finds one of Hitler smiling.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: There are so few public pictures of you smiling. THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Before I became Chancellor, there were none. Nor any with children or small animals. While Adolf continues looking at photos, Eva goes back to home movies. ON THE CELL SCREEN: Adolf with puppies running around at feet. He remains standing, stiff, unwilling to bend to th Then, images of Eva on an ocean liner.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The Iceland vacation was a joyous time for my sisters and me. You should have come with us. You were always inspired by the Viking sagas. (she pauses to remember) The only flaw in the trip was a delay before we departed from Hamburg. A family was removed from the ship...

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: (cuts her off) I had no time for holiday trips.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: The police came just before we were to leave. I'll never forget the cries of the woman. ADOLF (roars) Be quiet! Never mention that again.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: I don't understand how a family with children could be a threat to any of our... Adolf suddenly becomes extremely angry, knocks aside the and albums he's sorting. He jumps up and walks toward us he's EXTREMELY CLOSE.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: (grumbles under his breath) The greater the man, the more insignificant should be his woman. In the background, Eva waits for him to calm down. Like a retriever dog, she looks around for something to offer, p the photo album, brings it to him, holding it up. EVA (meek, 0.S.) THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 Look... It's a photo of herself when she was young, blonder and f (Hoffman 242-EB-32-1B). Adolf ignores her at first. Final looks at the photo. Eva hurries to ingratiate.

dialogues.speaker: EVA
dialogues.text: Did you like me better when I was blonde with baby fat or later when I was brunette and thin?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: (still dominant) I liked you when you were blonde and thin.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: stands in her own light. She is tall, black haired, domineering, dressed in a slee formal gown in the style of the thirties. Shoulders and c revealed, very white skin. Made up and styled to look mysterious, alluring. Her black dress blends with the dark background so that h -- from bust up -- seems to float in space.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PROJECTOR, HITLER'S ALONE, WITHOUT EVA
dialogues.text: He's still a little lost in the thought. After a beat, he smoothes back his hair, tries to recompose himself. He becomes aware of someone in the cell... turns.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Freud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room is SIGMUND FREUD, who appears as one woul expect: archetypal. As if in a classic portrait. Adolf keeps his eyes on Freud, steps towards him, circles Takes a posture of strength. ON THE CELL SCREEN behind him: abstract turbulence. FREUD keeps his eyes on Adolf, studying him. Adolf clearly doesn't like being measured. THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: You could never understand a man of will.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: You prefer the cloak of enigma.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: The problem with you Jews is you think you know so much. Freud looks back at him, indifferent.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: The inside of a man, this foolishness about the id, and... superego... A man is the sum total of his acts! Success justifies all.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Interesting. So, what can we learn from your actions?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: A man is his own creation, his own artwork. To use only reason is to close the door to the power of an idea like, "blood and soil."

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: What of your inner world?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: I know myself completely. I know my personal myths. That is enough. He walks away from Freud, stops, straightens his jacket. ON THE CELL SCREEN in the background: More abstract turbu made to look like a Rorschach test.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: With the answers to a thousand questions, you and your kind could not begin to understand me. Only a poet can touch the edge of the Fuhrer mystery. Freud carefully considers Adolf's words. ADOLF stares bac ominous intensity. Adolf then takes an abrupt, aggressive step towards Freud, rising even further in the THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 FREUD - slows to freeze frame, literally, with his hand f awkwardly at the tip of his beard. He is dehumanized. The also "freeze", clipped, echoing to nothing.

dialogues.speaker: THREE BLONDE CHILDREN, SIX YEARS OLD, PLAYING
dialogues.text: Two girls and a boy are sitting on his lap. Another girl with the hair of the first. Filling the frame, Adolf is surrounded by fair-haired youth. He's very playful, comfo more loose than he ever is with adults. They lift his spirits. He keeps them close as he dictates Typist.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: From Latvia to Lithuania. From Estonia to Slovakia. From Russia, from Poland to the Ukraine -- wherever we found them.... 250,000 blonde-haired, blue-eyed nuggets harvested for the Third Reich... (as an afterthought) Nordic nuggets, to lighten up the dark Bavarians. TYPIST (stops typing) We took children from their parents?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: They were misplaced Germans. We brought them home. ON THE TYPIST: He gazes at Hitler, as if he might questio further, but then nods and goes back to work.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: As the brush adds finishing detail, we PULL BACK to revea self-portrait of Adolf, which depicts him in an overcoat collar up, dramatically knight-like and "Aryan." Behind h the portrait are glorious, unpopulated mountains and plai living space. WAGNERIAN MUSIC accompanies his work. Along with TYPING. For reference, Adolf glances at a classical bust of the i Aryan - high cheek bones, square jaw, full lips and near nose.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 When I was a small boy in Linz, I frequently played alone. I would walk to the top of a hill overlooking the city. In dark solitude, I imagined that I had absolute command of those heights and all the lands below. Only the trees on the hillside heard my cry: HEIL HITLER! HEIL HITLER! Those private moments stayed with me through the darkest days. Adolf stops painting, satisfied at first. But as he scrut the self-portrait, insecurity re-emerges.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: The tragedy of every charismatic leader is to be imprisoned by his fate. His triumphs are finite, his needs infinite.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF'S HAND AUTOGRAPHS A POSTCARD PRINT OF THE PAINTI
dialogues.text: ADOLF (to the Typist, 0.S.) The Fuhrer cult was the fulfillment of a mysterious longing. We realize he's autographing a large stack of the postcar from the painting of himself.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nazism and Christianity are based on the same idea that one individual could provide salvation. A simple man from a small cottage... IN THE CELL, another photograph is autographed. ...could work a miracle of enlightenment and faith in a world of skepticism and despair. ON THE SCREEN: night rallies build to mystical ritual, to and giant red Nazi flags, storm troopers marching. Tribal animalistic, CHANTING. ADOLF (in cell to Typist) My need to control fulfilled others' need to be controlled. That was my euphoric discovery. The union of my urges and the German people's desires. THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 If you unite a powerful people whose first duty is obedience, you can do anything. (stops and thinks) God I loved order. Then daylight, and shots about the individual becoming pa larger cause, merging into the crowd. Then SIEG HEILS.

dialogues.speaker: CELL-SCREEN
dialogues.text: ADOLF (to himself) Every woman a potential source of soothing, warmth, love. Every man, a rival. Adolf walks into the shot, his back to us, silhouetted. Approaching the women. ADOLF (pre-lapped) "The most German of Beings."

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF'S CHIN LEANS ON THE HILT OF A MEDIEVAL SWORD
dialogues.text: Adolf lifts his head, puts the sword down.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: (continuing, 0.S. at first) ".,..I am the German spirit. Consider the incomparable magic of my works." We notice Freud. Hitler's back is to him.

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Did you write that? Adolf lifts a medieval book that lies open near him.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: ".,.the incomparable magic of my works." (turns to Freud) It's Wagner. He closes the ancient book, stands and recites from memor ADOLF (cont'd) "Man is a beast of prey, developing through constant progress. The beast conquers, founds great realms by the subjugation of other subjugators, forms states and organizes civilizations, in order to enjoy his booty in THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 peace... Attack and defense, suffering and struggle, domination and servitude, all sealed with blood...."

dialogues.speaker: FREUD
dialogues.text: Are those Wagner's words?

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: We are both illusionists and showmen.... I made my life so different, so vibrant, so extreme... This is how I have accumulated power. I wrapped blood and iron in a cloud of mystic communion with the German 'Volk.' (he extends the book, shaking it) Whoever wants to understand Hitler must first know Wagner. He drops the book for emphasis, notices that Freud is scr on his analyst's pad. Frustrated, Adolf suddenly jumps up the pad from Freud's hand. He crosses to the wood stove, opens the door, tosses it i embers. The pad FLAMES up.

dialogues.speaker: ON FREUD
dialogues.text: As Adolf approaches, defiant, hands him a new pad.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Here. Write this: Fire fascinates Hitler. It consumes without accepting or rejecting. He stares at Freud, daring him to analyze it and write. 39 OVER BLACK: FAINT, DISTANT SCREAMS. SERIES OF SHOTS DISSOLVE THROUGH: Black and white images abstract body forms that begin to evoke death. Hitler's i a warped mirror: grotesque. Ominous images of huge gears grinding together, dragging stills from "Triumph of the W into the machinery.

dialogues.speaker: A MIRROR
dialogues.text: He pulls his lip down, examines his front teeth. He rubs with his finger as if trying to scrub something off.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE CELL SCREEN
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 CELL SCREEN: Hitler riding in parades, past Hitler Youth, hysterical women. (We HEAR Adolf and Goebbels OFF SCREEN)

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Goebbels, did you write this speech?

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mmmm...

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: "To be allowed to be Adolf Hitler's mason, carpenter and lowliest day laborer is a gift of heaven."

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I always avoided exaggeration.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Ah, listen... From one of your speeches: "In the personality of Hitler, a million-fold longing of the German people has become reality..." What a thrill to play Fuhrer. For twelve years, the supreme father figure.

dialogues.speaker: GOEBBELS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A role to surpass even Lohengrin. By the end of the montage, Hitler's image is enlarged to point of extreme graininess, and slowed to almost a freez

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Read the last sentence back to me.

dialogues.speaker: TYPIST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "We made the sound so overwhelming, the attitude so certain, the level of force so high, the spectacle so grand, that no one could see anything at the center but the symbolism." REVEAL: A third child, his head, nose, etc., being measur adult hands, using scientific calipers.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 Yes, good. The symbolism at the center... TILT TO DISCOVER: Adolf is the adult doing the measuring.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: Like the sun. No one could look at me without the pain and punishment of blindness. Number two: The receptivity of the masses is unlimited, yet their understanding is feeble. They quickly forget. Three: The masses tell each other small lies. It would never come into their heads to construct colossal tales. Thus the bold myths work best. Four: Effective propaganda must be confined to stereotypes. Always focus people's attention on a single foe. To have multiple enemies confuses people. My genius was the combining of two enemies -- Jews and Marxism -- into one: Jewish Marxism. A synthesis that was key to my success. Weave this in: Crude simplifications, endlessly repeated will influence the supple -- Goebbels' realm. For the non-supple, the stubborn, terror is necessary -- Himmler's responsibility. The typist glances up at mention of the SS leader.

dialogues.speaker: A GIRL-CHILD'S HAND REACHES FOR ADOLF'S
dialogues.text: The BAVARIAN GIRL is six years old, blonde, dressed in fo Bavarian clothing. On the other side of Adolf is a nine-y BAVARIAN BOY. He leads them by the hand away from us. The view is diffused, dreamy. The sounds of an off-screen drown out the children's voices. Adolf lifts the little girl to see Germania, the model ci

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: This was to be built for you. She reacts. The nine-year old plays with toy soldiers fro checkpoint gates. THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 The children run off. We follow them until they exit fram We PUSH slowly toward the wall to discover reddish water in at the floor-wall seam, then up along the wall's surfa a vague outline of human ribs just below the plaster of t past a wall-painting of a half-man, half beast (inspired Stuck), then further along the wall...

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE CHILDREN, AT PLAY AND AT WORK, LOYAL TO THE PARTY.
dialogues.text: ADOLF (watching) We bred blondes. ADOLF.... leans near the opening in the wall, watching. T sight of the children seems painful to him. We watch through Adolf's eyes: more images of the innocen Germans, the future. Sadness wells up in him. The newsreel footage ends. The light reflecting back on Adolf flickers dimly, then g leaving him only in the bluish light from the opening in wall. He moves closer to it, seems to address someone on other side of the wall, conspiratorially.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: What will they think of us?.... History... those who study our lives? Will we be judged by what we say, by our deeds, by the monuments and images we leave behind...? (pauses to think) ...0r something else? Something we can't control? This is an unsettling thought: Not to be in control. The JAILER appears, his stick rattling along the surface cell, past the opening in the wall, whose light has sudde extinguished. Adolf is now across the room. CLOSE ON THE JAILER: His face, oblong, fills the frame.

dialogues.text: It would never occur to people that I am shy. He continues to wait awkwardly before speaking. But then adoring crowds, which fuel him as a speaker. Back and for between crowds encouraging him, to bigger and bigger mome speaker -- the crowds pushing the man instead of the othe around. Later in the same (or another) speech, his arm is out, hi fingers are shaking. The CAMERA suddenly jumps from his f his arm to his two shaking fingers. Huge ROARS of crowds. Adolf beams, prideful. Then deflates for a moment. Reflec It's never enough. It doesn't satisfy his boundless hunge FLASH CUT TO: Adolf's hand, his sleeve rolled up, his fis clenching and unclenching. dialogues.text: Light from the screen, from the admiration of the crowds, his face. Adolf walks into the beam, lifts his arms, clos eyes, turns his body slowly in the warmth. Adolf sits into his chair, still vaguely unsatisfied. A woman's hand slides into frame, caresses his cheek, sho neck... EVA. His hand touches her, warmly, acknowledging. (Read: "Keep touching me. Be here for me.") From the crowds on the screen. Great CHEERS.

dialogues.speaker: EVA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They adored you.

dialogues.speaker: ADOLF
dialogues.text: THE EMPTY MIRROR - final production script - June 5, 199 They were stupefied by the Fuhrer cult. ON THE CELL-SCREEN: The crowds are now hysterical in thei efforts to pay homage to Hitler. Men cheer, salute. Women throw flowers, reach out to him.
